The January issue of the Blue
Jay, monthly magazine published.
by the undergraduates of the Hopkins will be delivered on Friday
to subscribers. The issue is called
the"Pre-Exam Number" and plans
its cover to express that motif.
In its experimental stage the
Jay's editors have innovated several
new features this issue, and eliminated others whose popularity
was not up to par.
Announcements by the Jay's editors concerning interviews to business staff candidates will be made
as soon as the possibility of a scale
of commissions is examined.

In the Philadelphia Record
on Sathrday appeared an
account of the costly bravery of the Abraham Lincoln
Battalion at Teruel, its attempts to save Loyalist
troops trapped in fortifications. Their losses were terrific, and even General
Franco payed tribute to their courage, saying they
were the best troops his enemies had.
The heroism of these men in the front lines of the
anti-Fascist forces should not be considered stupid and
self-sacrificing. On the other hand, it should show ,us
more clearly in, what peril a'free government eleeted
by the people has been placed, when their mainstays
are "advanced" or "proletarian" democrats from other
republics. Especially when the ideas of these men when
translated into practice would mean dictatorship. It's
a riddle, but democracy in Spain does not mean clergy,
and Moors backed by Nazi.'end Fascist auxiliaries.

The Joh,ns Hopkins rifle team,
led by C. E. Lindenmeyer, manager and captain, scored a 12491318 victory over Georgetown in a
shoulder-to-shoulder match at the
nation's capital. This triumph was
the first win of the season for the
Jay sharpshooters.
Besides Lindenmeyer, M. J.
Hartke, J. T. Griffin, R. G. Brown,
W. B. Grey, M. J. Weber, J. S.
Baldwin, R. B. Stegmaier, and A.
H. Smith.
The president Of the Rifle Club
is R. B. Stegmaier, while W. B.
Grey is the secretary The club is
under the general supervision of
the R 0. T. d.; most of the matches being arranged by the Military
Science departments of various
schools. The men practice during
the week in the shooting gallery
located on the fourth floor of Gilman Hall.
The Jays will encounter Georgetown in a return match here at the
Johns Hopkins gallery. The team
because of its many experienced
veterans hope to continue their
good work, and take the Terrors
again. This contest will take place
on March 5.

urge men who are 'interested in
this spoit to report to the North
loft of Gilman Hall for information.

In the Philadelphia Record
on Sathrday appeared an
account of the costly bravery of the Abraham Lincoln
Battalion at Teruel, its attempts to save Loyalist
troops trapped in fortifications. Their losses were terrific, and even General
Franco payed tribute to their courage, saying they
were the best troops his enemies had.
The heroism of these men in the front lines of the
anti-Fascist forces should not be considered stupid and
self-sacrificing. On the other hand, it should show ,us
more clearly in, what peril a'free government eleeted
by the people has been placed, when their mainstays
are "advanced" or "proletarian" democrats from other
republics. Especially when the ideas of these men when
translated into practice would mean dictatorship. It's
a riddle, but democracy in Spain does not mean clergy,
and Moors backed by Nazi.'end Fascist auxiliaries.

The president of the club, Wallman, '40, said, "It is the wish of the
club, that Mr. Vaughan and many
experts of his calibre will again be
able to be presented in the near
future, and that more members will
avail themselves of the privileges extended by the Society to attend these
demonstrations, of value both to beginners and advanced photographers.
"Nudes" Photographer Programmed
"On February 11th the Society
will have the pleasure of presenting
Mr. Harvey Wobbe, one of the foremost pictorial and nude photographers in the country," he further announced. Mr. Wobbe represents the
Agfa Co., and ,will discuss the general subject Of Pictoral photography.
It is expected that many members
of the Baltimore Camera Club will
also be present. Mr. Wobbe has addressed that organization earlier in
the year, and they wish to hear him
again.
